title: Can I earn from creative common videos on youtube? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you use CC content, it’s likely that you won’t be able to monetize those videos with ads because you aren’t the original creator. If you’re able to build a large subscriber/viewer base, you can set up a crowdfunding account on a site like Patreon and some viewers may support you with small donations.you may be able to find businesses to sponsor your channel.The value of your channel may not be that the content is original, but that it is an aggregation of information on a specific topic. This value is lower if you simply clone an existing CC channel that has all of the same content. Keep in mind that one of the requirements of all CC licenses is attribution. In other words, you have to acknowledge and link back to the original work. I’m assuming that— you’re using the entire CC videos “as-is,” without changing them. Many CC videos on YouTube consist of content that’s intended to be edited into new content.you’re using CC videos found on YouTube. YouTube allows only one form of CC license, the attribution license. This license allows modifications and commercial use. If you use CC videos from other sources, those videos may be licensed under a more restrictive CC license. Be sure that you’re compliant with the terms of the CC license applied to the videos you use.Creating original content using some CC elements may allow you to monetize your videos with ads, but I’m not 100% certain about that. You would still need to attribute any CC content to the original creators and indicate that you had modified their work to create your video.

You can earn from anything you post on YouTube. But to activate monetisation on your videos you will need atleast 10k channel views. (Earlier monetisation could be started with 0 views but now YouTube has changed it's policy) After you'll activate monetisation then whenever an advertisement is displayed while your video is being played you will get paid! So if you think using videos with creative common license can get you 10k views, go for it! But you need to be careful while choosing videos with creative common license. Some channels may have copied the content from a standard licensed video and kept that video as a creative common licensed video in their channel. After you upload that video on your channel and if the original creator finds that, you may have a copyright strike! If you get 3 copyright strikes your channel will be terminated! I would advise you to create your original content and earn through it!

You can earn adsense from creative commons videos and you can earn from pre-roll and post roll ads that you place yourself as long as you don’t edit the video itself. It really depends on the license of the video though, as most creative commons license is for non-commercial use. Creative Commons - Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 United States - CC BY-NC 3.0 US Creative Commons - Attribution 4.0 International - CC BY 4.0 Creative Commons - Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International - CC BY-SA 4.0 Creative Commons - Attribution-NoDerivatives 4.0 International - CC BY-ND 4.0 Creative Commons - Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International - CC BY-NC-SA 4.0 Creative Commons - Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International - CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

Yes its possible if you know what you are doing. Here are the steps to follow Get a clickbank account (for finding a product to sell, clickbank also will help with the transaction between you and the product owner.)Go to youtube and make a search using the targeted keyword of the product you want to promoteFilter your search to creative common and start downloading the videosYou can edit the videos if you choose (add some call to action graphics that points viewers to the description box of your videoLink to the product you are sell.Here is a video that will show you 4 other ways to make money with creative common videos on youtube  https://tubemechanicsnotes.com/

Did you know that you can make money on YouTube without ever uploading a video? YouTube allows it's users access to a library of videos that fall under the Creative Commons license. This License allows you to use other people's YouTube videos (and make money from them) as if they were your own. Yes you can. Creative common videos are available to be monetized on YouTube as they are based on the concept of free reuse and distribution of original works. Anyone can republish and re purpose those videos to create brand new content and even earn money from it. Go to my Profile and you can find all about YouTube material there...

It is possible but it would be difficult. One of the benefits of creative commons videos is you can upload them wherever you want. So people do. That means there are lots of copies of creative commons videos on lots of different sites. So you would have plenty of competition. Also since you are not creating your own videos, just uploading creative commons videos, your channel would probably not generate many subscribers as there would be no theme or reason to subscribe. So you would probably struggle to get the views you need to make money. But if you think you want to try, go for it! The key is to just start.

Yes you can earn, you can monetize CREATIVE COMMONS content If the owner of the content allows you to do commercially. I created a Youtube Channel regarding music, all the videos I uploaded there fall into the category of ATTRIBUTION 4.0 INTERNATIONAL (CC BY 4.0) .This means I am free to SHARE (copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format and ADAPT (remix, transform, and build upon the material for any purpose, even commercially. The licensor cannot revoke these freedoms as long as you follow the licensed terms. This terms include PROPER ATTRIBUTION (I must give the appropriate credit, provide a link to the license and indicate if changes were made. https://lc-s.co/CXwYG

Yes you can. Creative common videos are available to be monetized on YouTube as they are based on the concept of free reuse and distribution of original works. Anyone can republish and re purpose those videos to create brand new content and even earn money from it. There may be some videos which have conditional reuse terms for e.g. they might require you to give due credit to the owners or any other such condition. Do check the terms of the video before using it.

So, money for nothing? Just find other content on the internet and recycle it, hoping to make a buck? While that plan is legal, because you specified Creative Commons content, it's not going to work. To qualify for monetization, your channel needs 1,000 subscribers. I don't see that happening. Further, in one years time you need to get 4,000 view-hours. So enough people have to watch videos all the way through to reach that total. And after all that.you get to start running ads. You'll need tens of thousands of new views to make anything bankable. How much do YouTubers make when each of their videos get 50k, 100k, 500k, 1m, and 1.5m views? What about even more than that? Why would people watch videos already found online, no changes made at all?

Yes you can. Creative common videos are available to be monetized on YouTube as they are based on the concept of free reuse and distribution of original works. Anyone can republish and re purpose those videos to create brand new content and even earn money from it. According to the YouTube Partner Program requirements, you need at least 1,000 subscribers to be eligible to monetize your account through their program. ... As you already know, the amount of money you can make on YouTube varies due to the nature of ads and what kind of viewership you have. Go to my Profile and you can find all about YouTube Monetization material there...

The point of Creative Commons is to allow the use of a work and retain some “credit” for the work without pay. Under a Creative Commons license, developers typically will allow the use of the work for non-commercial use, for commercial use, and with modification as long as you give credit to the creator. Creative Common licenses do not include a structure to make content available to collect a fee.

You can grab best pieces of such video and combine them into much shorter teasers or trailers for such videos to easier attract your viewers’ attention and monetize them as any other videos on Youtube. Do not think of such your teaser or trailer as a straightforward summary of the main content. However, your video will be engrossing if you treat it like an independent mini-story or experience, here are some good examples and tips to make a good teaser: A Comprehensive Guide to Making Effective Teasers and Trailers First of all, decide what mood you want to create. Because teaser videos are so short, you can usually evoke one emotion — maybe two.Once you have an emotion in mind, it’s far easier to choose the shots, music, and text you’ll include (it also could be from creative commons).

Yes you can. Creative common videos are available to be monetized on YouTube as they are based on the concept of free reuse and distribution of original works. Anyone can republish and re purpose those videos to create brand new content and even earn money from it. Creative Commons is a system that allows you to legally use “some rights reserved” music, movies, images, and other content — all for free. CC offers free copyright licenses that anyone can use to mark their creative work with the freedoms they want it to carry. Go to my Profile and you can find all about YouTube Monetization material there...

Yes you can but not from ad revenue. You can use others videos and put an affiliate link in the description and earn from affiliate marketing programs. Say if you upload a travel related video then you can put a travel related affiliate link in description and if your viewers happen to see then purchase something from your affiliate link then you earn money.

I think it all depends on the CC license. If you are permitted to use it for commercial purposes, then I’m pretty sure you can monetize it. If you can’t, that is the same as not owning the rights in the first place.
Yes you can monetize Creative Commons Content if the owner of the content allows you to do so commercially. Sometimes the owner may want you to give credits to him or purchase the content.
Can i earn from uploading creative common videos on my youtube channel
